study.title: Extended-spectrum β-lactamase and carbapenemase producing Enterobacteriaceae among patients suspected with surgical site infection at Hospitals in Southern Ethiopia

design.inclusion_criteria_text: Patients who were clinically suspected of having surgical site infection.

eligibility.population: Patients clinically suspected of having surgical site infection at two hospitals in Sodo Town, Southern Ethiopia.
eligibility.intervention: Not specified; clinical management and laboratory testing for ESBL and carbapenemase-producing Enterobacteriaceae.

populations.description: All patients clinically suspected of SSI at two hospitals in Sodo Town, Southern Ethiopia.
populations.comorbidities_key: Diabetes 6.4%, HIV/AIDS 2.6%, chronic liver disease 0.5%, heart failure 1.2%, immunosuppressive (long term steroid) 6.6%

provenance.section_heading: Clinical and medical status of the study participants
provenance.text_snippet: A total of 422 participants were admitted to the study. Of these, 221 (52.4%) were from the orthopedics ward, 112 (26.5%) from the surgery ward, and 89 (21.1%) from the Obstetrics and Gynecology Unit.

definitions.resistance_definition_text: Sensitive, intermediate and resistant according to Clinical Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines.
definitions.outcome_definitions_text: SSI defined by CDC criteria; ESBL confirmed by double-disc synergy test; carbapenemase by modified Hodge test.

lab_methods.specimen_collection_method: Swabs and aspirates collected aseptically from suspected SSI patients; swabs rotated on 1 cm2 area of clean granulation tissue for 5 seconds; aspirates collected with 5 ml syringe.
lab_methods.culture_method: Specimens cultured on blood agar and MacConkey agar; incubated at 37°C for 24–48 h; colony morphology, Gram stain, and biochemical tests for identification.
lab_methods.QC_measures: Sterility of culture media confirmed; 5% of media incubated overnight; standard reference strains used for ESBL and carbapenemase controls.
lab_methods.organism_identification_method: Colony morphology, Gram staining, standard biochemical tests.
lab_methods.contamination_handling: Specimens delayed were put in Amies transport medium.
lab_methods.lab_capacity_notes: Specimens processed at Sodo Christian General Hospital Microbiology Laboratory; carbapenemase confirmation at Ethiopia Public Health Institute.

amr_proportions.mdr_definition_text: MDR: resistant to at least one agent in three or more antimicrobial categories.
amr_proportions.notes: ESBL and carbapenemase rates reported for E. coli.

provenance.section_heading: Antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of extended-spectrum β-lactamase and carbapenemase producing Enterobacterales

amr_proportions.mdr_definition_text: MDR: resistant to at least one agent in three or more antimicrobial categories.
amr_proportions.notes: All K. pneumoniae isolates resistant to cefepime.

provenance.section_heading: Antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of extended-spectrum β-lactamase and carbapenemase producing Enterobacterales

amr_proportions.mdr_definition_text: MDR: resistant to at least one agent in three or more antimicrobial categories.
amr_proportions.notes: High susceptibility to meropenem among E. coli.

provenance.section_heading: Antimicrobial susceptibility pattern of extended-spectrum β-lactamase and carbapenemase producing Enterobacterales

length_of_stay.notes: Length of hospital stay reported in categories: 1–7 days (32.5%), 8–14 days (34.8%), >15 days (32.7%).

provenance.section_heading: Clinical and medical status of the study participants
provenance.text_snippet: Length of medical stay in hospital: 1–7 days 137 (32.5%), 8–14 days 147 (34.8%), >15 days 138 (32.7%)

risk_factors_effects.exposure: Length of hospital stay (8–14 days vs 1–7 days)
risk_factors_effects.notes: Length of hospital stay was independently associated with SSI due to ESBL-producing Enterobacteriaceae.

provenance.section_heading: TABLE 6 Bivariate and multivariate logistic regression analysis
provenance.text_snippet: Length of medical stay in hospital...AOR = 3.81 (95% CI 2.08–6.95)

codes.subtheme: resistance patterns and rates by pathogen/antibiotic
codes.summary: High rates of ESBL (46%) and carbapenemase (15%) producing Enterobacteriaceae were found among SSI suspects, with predominant resistance to cefepime, ceftriaxone, ceftazidime, and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid.

evidence_quotes.quote: Of 69 Enterobacteriaceae isolates, 66.6 % (46/69) were positive for ESBL production, and 21.7 (15/69) were positive for carbapenemase-producing Enterobacteriaceae.
The majority of Enterobacteriaceae isolates showed sensitivity to meropenem (72.1%); however revealed 63.9% and 70.5% were resistant to gentamicin and ciprofloxacin, respectively.

codes.location_context: Southern Ethiopia, Wolaita Sodo Comprehensive Specialized Hospital and Sodo Christian General Hospital

provenance.text_snippet: Of 69 Enterobacteriaceae isolates, 66.6 % (46/69) were positive for ESBL production, and 21.7 (15/69) were positive for carbapenemase-producing Enterobacteriaceae.

codes.subtheme: inappropriate use, IPC gaps, diagnostics delays, policy failures, supply chain, workforce, patient factors
codes.summary: Overuse of antibiotics, self-medication, prescribing without susceptibility testing, and prolonged hospital stays are contributing factors to ESBL and CPE prevalence.

evidence_quotes.quote: The issue of ESBL in developing countries has been made severe by the overuse of antibiotics, overdosing, self-medication, prescribing medications without conducting the proper susceptibility testing, and extended hospital stays.

provenance.text_snippet: The issue of ESBL in developing countries has been made severe by the overuse of antibiotics, overdosing, self-medication, prescribing medications without conducting the proper susceptibility testing, and extended hospital stays.

codes.summary: Advancements in infection prevention and control practices have occurred, but SSIs remain a major cause of prolonged hospital stays, morbidity, and mortality.

evidence_quotes.quote: While there have been advancements in infection prevention and control practices, such as better ventilation of surgical sites, surgical techniques, barriers, and the availability of antimicrobials or antibiotics used for prophylaxis, surgical site infections (SSIs) still account for a major cause of prolonged hospital stays, morbidity, and mortality.

provenance.text_snippet: While there have been advancements in infection prevention and control practices...

codes.summary: Research on ESBL and CPE for SSI is lacking in developing nations like Ethiopia, especially in southern regions.

evidence_quotes.quote: Yet, research on ESBL and CPE for SSI is lacking in developing nations like Ethiopia, and no study has previously examined the prevalence of ESBL and CPE with SSI in the southern Ethiopian region of Wolaita.

provenance.text_snippet: no study has previously examined the prevalence of ESBL and CPE with SSI in the southern Ethiopian region of Wolaita.

provenance.section_heading: Sample size determination and sampling technique
provenance.text_snippet: clinical criteria for surgical site infection development (deep incisional surgical site infection, organ/space any surgical site infection, and superficial incisional surgical site infection) from any surgical site infection categorization system from the CDC guidelines were used
